titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Continuing the perusal of Mr Johnson’s Treatise upon Language. I find him in Lecture disclaiming with great earnestness any intention to unsettle the belief of divine revelation in the holy Scriptures. So does Benjamin Constant— So did the Count de Buffon in his correspondence with the Sorbonne— I believe Johnson sincere; and he declares emphatically that he never would have published his Lectures if he had believed his theory incompatible with faith in divine revelation— Dr. Johnson supposes that Pope did not know that his optimism in the Essay on Man was fatalism; and Alexander B. in excluding religious faith from the conclusions of his own argument assigns no reason for the exception. The general tenor of his argument is that words have no signification except as reports of the physical senses— That all knowledge consists of sights, sounds, feels, tastes and smells—but in his classification he admits another class of thoughts which he calls verbal; and in another Lecture he allows internal feelings to be also a source of thoughts— The words mind, and idea, are totally excluded from his vocabulary— His broad Theory is that language is and can be significant of nothing but Sensation— And as this doctrine makes of the universe a mass of sensuality without Soul, and without reasoning faculty, he runs foul of natural religion of theism of mathematics of metaphysics—of all art and all Science, protesting all the time that he means no harm to religion— Mr Johnson is a remarkable instance of the misfortune of intense and incessant meditation, destitute of dear conception— Morning visit from Mr Taliaferro, to whom I gave a copy of my Eulogy on James Madison.— Mr Pedrich, and Dr Todsen came and I went with them to the old Episcopal church at Georgetown, where I saw his groups of statuary, his busts of Mr Van Buren, Mr Clay, and Mr Joseph R. Ingersoll and his designs for Basso Relievo Sculpture in a Church. He was urgent to have my opinion of his works, and I could not give it for it was not favourable I could not flatter and was unwilling to discourage him.— His groups are mere commonplace imitation of the antique— His allegorical faces very uncaptivating; and his busts no likenesses— It was unfortunate for him that there were in the same building busts of Mr Woodbury, the Secretary and of Mr Preston the Senator from South-Carolina by Hiram Power of Kentucky, and superior as likenesses and as works of art to the busts by Mr Pedrich— His designs for Bas Relief embrace 84 Subjects Half from the old and half from the new Testament— They are in the Classical Style of Italian Painting, and represent God almighty in the form of an old man with a hooked nose, a bushy beard rolled up in thirty or forty yards of blanketing. Then he represents the Patriarchs Abraham and Isaac in precisely the same form, and in the same costume— Mr Pedrich has a recommendation from his master Thorwaldsen certifying that he has considerable talent, which is unquestionable; but he has not that ideal conception of grace and beauty which is the perfection of Sculpture and Painting, and without which the mere imitation of nature, physical nature, is
fit only for Signposts and Milestones.— On returning home after a visit to the Bank of the Metropolis, I found at my door a person named George Cameron, who exhibited to me drawings of an invention for guarding the boilers of Steam engines from explosion; for which he said he had a patent; and he had a petition to the Secretary of the Navy; for the sum of 300 dollars to make experiments of his invention— He complained that the Secretary of the Navy had refused him the money, and as I had neither power nor will to redress that grievance, he said he would lay his invention, before a Committee of Congress— To this I had no objection— The man had as Wise said of Silas Wright a Cognac face. and he had burnished it before coming here— Just before dinner I received the proof slips from the National Intelligencer Office of that part of my Eulogy on Madison which is to be published in the paper to-morrow Morning— I had corrected it and took the opportunity to rectify an error in the pamphlet, which stated the numbers of Publius at 86—they were 85— After dinner it occurred to me to correct another error into which I had fallen in enumerating the numbers of the federalist written by Mr Madison. I had omitted the numbers 62 and 63— I wrote a note correcting this error, and enclosed it to the Foreman of the National Intelligencer, with a request that it might be subjoined to the part of the Eulogy to be published in the daily paper to-morrow— Mary and Elizabeth spent the Evening at Mrs W. S. Smith— I went for them and walked home with them between 9 and 10 O’Clock
2. VI:30. Friday. My Grand daughter Mary-Louisa 8. years old.

Giusta was here this morning— Part of my Eulogy was published in the National intelligencer of this morning; but my note which I had enclosed to the foreman was not printed; nor was my correction of the proof reducing the numbers of Publius from 86 to 85 substituted for the original error. I called at the shop of the Bookbinder Blake, with a collection of pamphlets to be bound in a Volume concerning the boundary controversy between Michigan and Ohio; and I met there John F. Sullivan, an Irishman, much implicated in the warfare between President Jackson, and the Bank of the United States— He has opened here a Stationer’s shop, and shewed me sundry samples of writing paper of various sizes, but none of them of the precise size that I wanted— Our manufacturers of paper have gone into the practice of making their paper almost entirely of cotton, and the paper has consequently no tenacity of texture; it falls to pieces in the mere act of folding it up— I stop’d also at Fischer’s shop, and examined many samples of paper but found none to suit me— I was twice at the Office of the National Intelligencer— I was anxious to correct the error in my Eulogy, with regard to the numbers of Publius, and in omitting the numbers 62 and 63. in the enumeration of those written by Mr Madison— How it happened that my note, sent yesterday to the foreman was not published was explained as well as it could be— It was the invincible carelessness of the compositors—my corrections of the proof were given to them; and they forgot to use them— To make assurance with regard to the facts doubly sure, I went to the Capitol, and at the Library, examined all the Editions of the Federalist which they have there; and they are three— The first edition in which the papers were collected, published at New-York in two duodecimo Volumes in 1788— This copy belonged to Mrs Elizabeth Hamilton, and was by
her given to her Sister, Mrs. Angelica Church, from whom it passed into the Library of Mr Jefferson, and with that was purchased by Congress— On a blank page before the title page of the first Volume of this copy, there is a minute in the hand-writing of Mr Jefferson as follows.
The rest of the work by Alexander Hamilton.

and immediately under this are certificates dated 13. Jany 1829. signed by Richd Harrison, and Joseph Nourse that the above minute is in the hand-writing of Thomas Jefferson— The Librarian shewed me also an Article in the National Register of 5. April 1817.—to this effect—that in the National Intelligencer of the preceding 10th. of March, there was a statement as from unquestionable authority, with a list varying from this one minuted by Mr Jefferson with regard to the number 21. instead of 20— To this there was a reply in the New-York Evening Post affirming that Genl. Hamilton, a day or two previous to his death stopped into the office of his friend judge Benson, then absent, and in the presence of his clerks left a paper in a book lying there and departed. After his fall, this paper was observed, and deposited by judge Benson in the City Library with a certificate that it was the hand writing of A. Hamilton— The following is a copy. Nos. 2. 3. 4. 5. 54. Mr Jay. Nos. 10. 14. 37 to 48 inclusive. Mr Madison Nos. 18. 19. 20. Mr Hamilton and Mr Madison jointly—all the rest by Mr. Hamilton.— It is apparent that this Memorandum made in the agitation of mind which tortured Hamilton, from the time of his acceptance of Burr’s challenge, was inaccurate by a defect of memory— It claimed for himself the numbers from 48 to 58, with the exception of 54. which it assigned to Mr Jay, but all of which were certainly written by Mr Madison— It claimed also the numbers 62. and 63 written by Mr Madison, and 64 written by Mr Jay—and it is most probable that the mistake by which he thought himself the author of the numbers from 48 to 58. caused the other mistake which ascribed to Mr Jay N. 54. instead of 64 which he really wrote— The minute was evidently written from mere memory without recurrence to the book, and under the perturbation of an impending fatal duel— The two other Editions of the Federalist, in the Library of Congress, are that published by Gideon in 1818. and the republication of it by Thompson and Homans in 1831— In that of 1818 the papers written by Mr Madison, were revised and corrected by himself—and it was printed from a copy of a former edition lent by him to the publisher, with his own marginal notes— From these it appears that the numbers 18. 19. and 20. were the joint composition of Madison and Hamilton, and that Mr Jefferson’s minute claiming for Madison the number 21. and not claiming the number 20. was so far incorrect— I returned to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and fixed with Mr Seaton the Note to be published with the remnant of the Eulogy to-morrow. I then returned home to dinner— Mrs W. S. Smith was here part of the afternoon, and we consumed the Evening at whist.

Mr William Brent was here this morning, and left with me a Memorial from his brother, Daniel Brent; Consul at Paris, praying for some addition to his Compensation, which he requested me to present, and to support so far as I might think just and proper which I readily promised— Mr Brent asked me for a copy of my Eulogy on Mr Madison for himself; and one for his brother.— I had none left to spare of the copies that I brought with me from Quincy; but having written to Mr Eastburn for more, I promised to Mr Brent when I should receive the next packet the two copies— I received this morning a note from Mr Bradley the Secretary of the Franklin Insurance company, inviting me to attend at a Meeting of the Directors of the Company at 4 O Clock this afternoon, at which the propositions that I had made were to be considered— I accordingly attended the Meeting which consisted of the President and Secretary and three Directors, Elder, Coyle and another— A desultory conversation was held upon my propositions, which I repeated, and which were discussed— Mr Grammer the President, read the Memorial now before Congress for a continuance and modification of the Charter; which unless renewed, will expire in 1838— On full reflection I said I thought the reserved fund required by the act of incorporation, and which has been raised, could not be converted into capital paid in, and distributed as Stock, but by increasing the capital itself, and still holding the Notes of the Stockholders to the full extent of their present amount— Mr Elder was opposed to any alteration of the Charter, except as requested by the memorial before Congress— Mr Coyle moved that the whole subject should be referred to a Committee of three of the Directors, whom he named and the vote was adopted accordingly— The meeting was adjourned, and I came home between six and seven, and we passed the remainder of the Evening at cards.

Thoroughly chilled this morning before breakfast by sitting and reading upwards of two hours in my chamber without a fire—reading Alexander B. Johnson’s Treatise upon Language— At morning worship, I heard Mr Fowler from Matthew 6.10. “Thy kingdom come”— Mr Fowler remarked that in the Lord’s prayer, from which his text was taken, there were three petitions, referring to God, and three to the supplicant himself, and his fellow creatures of the human race— This had never occurred to me, but it is so— There is another observation respecting the Lord’s prayer which deserves notice; and that is that the petitioner always speaks in the plural number— It is a social prayer—in which every individual supplicates for others at the same time as for himself—for others indefinitely, for all who pray at the same time; or rather for all human kind. Mr Fowler is a young man, exceedingly earnest, but not overbearing in his manner—very plain in his Discourse, but evidently sincere in every word that he utters. Mr W. S. Smith, Elizabeth C. Adams, and Elizabeth De Wint were at Church with me— Elizabeth C. Adams, dined at Mrs Smith’s— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas J dined with us, and we had visits before dinner from Major Massias, and Mrs Stewart.
After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the second Sunday in advent, and preached from Proverbs 24.30. “I went by the field of the slothful, and by the vineyard of the man void of understanding; 31. And lo, it was all grown over with thorns, and nettles had covered the face thereof, and the stone wall thereof was broken down”— How forcible is this picture of the effects of Sloth— How much more impressive than a precept enjoining diligence— Mr Hawley’s Sermon is an old one; but he has a partiality for texts from the Book of Proverbs; which I wish was shared by many of his clerical brethren. After Church we had visits from Mr Bailey the member from Maine, and Mrs. Bailey who was once Charlotte Welsh— Mrs Smith and Elizabeth De Wint remained here to tea, and Mr Smith came afterwards for them— I received Letters from N. Biddle, and from Charles J. Ingersoll, in adverse interests— Ingersoll sends me a printed opinion of his, affirming the right of the Legislature of Pennsylvania to repeal the Charter of the Bank of the United States— Mr Biddle mentions that he has sent to the National Gazette a Letter addressed to me, to be followed by another— I suppose on the same Subject— He said something of such an intention to me, when I last passed through Philadelphia.

Precisely at Noon James K. Polk Speaker of the House of Representatives of the United States, took the Chair of the House. The roll of names of the members was called over alphabetically by States, beginning with Maine; 15 answered at the first call— The names of the absentees were then called and
